title-group.article-title: Warrants in Initial Public Offerings: Empirical Evidence*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2001 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We investigate why firms include warrants in their initial public offerings (IPOs). We use a data set of Australian IPOs to examine two hypotheses about the inclusion of warrants in an IPO. The agency‐cost hypothesis emphasizes the need for sequential financing for relatively young firms, because sequential financing reduces the opportunities for managers to squander money on unprofitable projects. The signaling hypothesis focuses on the choice of securities as a signaling mechanism in a market characterized by information asymmetry. The evidence favors the signaling hypothesis, thus contributing to our understanding of the types of securities issued by firms.

fn.p: We thank the editor; an anonymous referee; Philip Brown and Richard Fayle (University of Western Australia); Phil Dolan and Dave Rickards (Macquarie Bank); Garry Twite (Australian Graduate School of Management); Peter Verhoeven (Curtin University of Technology); and participants at workshops at the University of Western Australia, the University of Kansas, and the University of Missouri—Columbia for helpful comments.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this study, we investigate package initial public offerings (PIPOs). Our primary purpose is to examine two competing but not mutually exclusive hypotheses about the inclusion of warrants in initial public offerings (IPOs). The agency‐cost hypothesis of Schultz (1993b ) emphasizes the need for sequential financing for relatively young firms, because sequential financing reduces the opportunities for managers to squander money on unprofitable projects. Using U.S. data, Schultz finds support for the agency‐cost hypothesis. The signaling hypothesis of Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) focuses on the choice of securities as a signaling mechanism in a market characterized by information asymmetry. We use a sample of Australian IPOs to test these two theories.

We define PIPOs as IPOs of common stock and warrants. In Australia, warrants are called “share options.” In the United States, IPOs of shares and warrants are referred to as “unit” offerings. However, a “unit offering” in Australia is an IPO of units, the equivalent of ordinary shares issued by a trust (mutual fund). To avoid confusion, we use the term “package IPO” to refer to an offering of shares and warrants. A typical Australian PIPO is that of Alcaston Mining N.L. In July 1987, Alcaston offered 8 million share‐and‐warrant packages, each consisting of one share of stock and one warrant. The price of the package was A$0.26. According to the prospectus, the offering price of the share was A$0.25, and the price of the warrant was A$0.01, although the securities could only be bought as a package. The warrant had an exercise price of A$0.25 and could be exercised between July 1, 1988, and July 1, 1990. After the IPO, the warrant could be detached from the share and was transferable.

This research is important for at least three reasons. First, a significant proportion of firms that go public choose to sell warrants in addition to common stock. In our sample of 394 Australian IPOs issued from 1979 to 1990, 134 (34%) are package IPOs. Schultz (1993b ) reports that 167 of 797 IPOs (21%) in the United States included warrants over the period 1986–88.

Second, we use a large sample of Australian IPOs to conduct empirical tests of the two major theories of package IPOs. The environmental setting (e.g., exchange listing requirements, taxes) in Australia differs from that in the United States, thus making possible a test of the robustness of the agency explanation for package IPOs. Further, our investigation provides the first comprehensive empirical tests of the signaling model presented in Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997). The research thus enhances our understanding of the types of financial instruments issued by firms.

The article is organized as follows. The next section discusses the agency‐cost and signaling hypotheses and their testable implications.Section IIIdescribes the sample.Section IVreports our findings.Section Vsummarizes and concludes.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Agency‐Cost Hypothesis
sec.p: Schultz (1993b ) argues that IPOs that include warrants are a type of “staged financing,” analogous to sequential financing by venture capital firms. Studies such as Sahlman (1990) note that in venture capital, this sequencing of cash infusions is a response to agency costs associated with free cash flows (Jensen1986).

The advantage of a package IPO is that it bonds the managers to optimal investment decisions. A package offering provides relatively little cash at the IPO, thus mitigating the free cash flow problem. A PIPO also induces managers to invest in projects that disclose the true prospects of the firm. If managers fail to make value‐revealing investments, the stock price stays below the warrant exercise price, and a second round of financing (warrant exercise) does not materialize. If the initial investment shows that the project is profitable, the stock price rises, the warrants are exercised, and the second round of financing occurs. If the initial investment shows that the project has a negative net present value (NPV), the stock price falls, and the second round of financing does not occur, as is in the best interests of shareholders.

The agency‐cost hypothesis has several testable implications, five of which are tested in Schultz (1993b ). Firms with greater ex ante uncertainty about their value will be more likely to choose PIPOs. Schultz argues that this uncertainty can be measured in several ways. Because there is typically more uncertainty about the profitability of the prospective investments of newer firms, the agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that firms choosing PIPOs will be younger than firms choosing shares‐only IPOs (SIPOs).

Greater ex ante uncertainty could depend on firm size. Under the agency‐cost hypothesis, firms that issue PIPOs have not yet made substantial investments in products or technologies and are therefore small. Thus, the agency‐cost hypothesis suggests that PIPOs will be more likely to be associated with smaller firms than SIPOs, as measured by either market value or total assets.

Another measure of uncertainty is the post‐IPO standard deviation of returns (Beatty1989). Hence, the agency‐cost hypothesis also predicts that PIPO firms will have greater return volatility than SIPO firms.

Firms are more likely to choose PIPOs if managers own a smaller post‐IPO proportion of the firm’s equity, thus reducing the cost to them of making poor investments. That is, firms with lower levels of managerial ownership have greater agency costs and will be more likely to choose a package IPO.

Firms that choose PIPOs should have greater agency conflicts than firms that use shares‐only IPOs. Following Ang, Cole, and Lin (2000), we use efficiency ratios to compare the agency costs of PIPO firms with those of SIPO firms.

The agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that the exercise price of the warrants is set above the expected stock price. As discussed above, this warrant provision motivates managers to discover and disclose the presence of profitable projects.

Two implications of the agency‐cost hypothesis concern the longer‐term viability and financing of PIPO firms. Because a package offering forces managers to determine the profitability of the prospective project(s), many firms that use package offerings will discover that they have no positive NPV projects. Thus, another testable implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis is that, relative to shares‐only IPO firms, fewer of the package IPO firms will survive. The agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that those PIPO firms that do survive are likely to receive additional equity infusions because the value‐revealing investment has established the attractiveness of their investment opportunity set.

Finally, the agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that, after controlling for other determinants of underpricing, package IPOs will be more underpriced than shares‐only IPOs. Given their (young) age and (small) size, firms that choose PIPOs have greater uncertainty about their prospects, which will lead to greater underpricing (see, e.g., Beatty and Ritter1986; and Grinblatt and Hwang1989).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: The Signaling Hypothesis
sec.p: Ross (1977) was the first to propose the idea that in an environment of information asymmetry, warrants can serve as a signaling mechanism. Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) present a signaling model in which insiders have private information about both the riskiness and the quality (expected value) of the firm. In their model, “good” firms, those with high expected future cash flows, can be riskier, less risky, or as risky as “bad” firms. Risk‐averse insiders of good firms choose the fraction of equity retained, the degree of underpricing, and the number of warrants (if any) that will maximize their utility. Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) demonstrate the conditions under which a separating equilibrium exists in which only good firms of relatively high risk will issue warrants with common stock. This model is not exclusive of the agency‐cost explanation for the inclusion of warrants in IPOs but provides a competing explanation.

Particularly relevant to our study is Chemmanur and Fulghieri’s (1997) proposition 3, which shows that if a good firm has sufficiently high risk, its equilibrium strategy includes equity with warrants (i.e., PIPO), the warrant subscription price equal to the expected value of the stock, underpricing of the package, and a positive portion of its equity retained by insiders.

The intuition behind this model is that underpricing, equity retention by insiders, and the inclusion of warrants in an IPO are all costly signals of firm quality. Warrants are costly because they mean sharing firm value with warrant holders if a favorable state of nature occurs. However, this cost occurs only if there is a higher realization of the firm’s future value, a circumstance under which the marginal value of the firm’s cash flows to insiders is relatively low. Thus, in utility terms, the personal cost to insiders of sharing via warrants is relatively small.
The signaling hypothesis has six testable implications:

list-item.p: firms that use PIPOs will have greater variability of future cash flows than firms that use shares‐only IPOs, that is, PIPO firms will be riskier than SIPO firms, as measured by return volatility;
after controlling for the proportion of firm value sold as warrants, the fraction of equity retained by insiders in PIPOs will decrease with firm riskiness;

because signaling is meaningful only in the context of information asymmetry, we conjecture that PIPO firms will exhibit higher levels of information asymmetry than will SIPO firms. We follow Krishnaswami, Spindt, and Subramaniam (1999) and Krishnaswami and Subramaniam (1999), measuring information asymmetry by residual standard deviation;
as noted above, the signaling hypothesis predicts that the exercise price of the warrants is set equal to the expected stock price;
in all IPOs (both with and without warrants), the degree of underpricing will increase with firm riskiness;

for PIPO firms, after controlling for the fraction of equity retained by insiders, the proportion of firm value sold as warrants will increase with firm riskiness. Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997, p. 19) comment on this prediction, saying, “We believe that there is as yet no empirical work testing this hypothesis, so that this prediction can perhaps serve as a test of our model.”

sec.p:
Table 1summarizes the predictions of the two theories. Although these competing models are not mutually exclusive, they are empirically distinguishable. While they agree on the type of firm that will issue warrants (young, small, risky), each has a number of unique predictions. Table 1
Summary of Predictions
Subject of Prediction Agency‐Cost Hypothesis Signaling Hypothesis
Types of firms that include warrants in their IPOs PIPO firms will be younger, smaller, and riskier than SIPO firms PIPO firms will be riskier than SIPO firms
Inside ownership PIPO firms will have lower levels of inside ownership For PIPO firms, insider ownership will decrease with riskiness, ceteris paribus
Other firm characteristics PIPO firms will have greater agency costs than SIPO firms PIPO firms will have higher levels of information asymmetry than SIPO firms
Exercise price Set above expected stock price Set equal to expected stock price
Survival rates PIPO firms will fail at a higher rate than SIPO firms No prediction
Subsequent financing Surviving PIPO firms are more likely to receive additional equity infusions than are SIPO firms No prediction
Underpricing Ceteris paribus, PIPO firms will be more underpriced than SIPO firms For all firms, underpricing will increase with firm riskiness
Proportion of firms sold as warrants No prediction Ceteris paribus, the proportion of firm value sold as warrants increases with firm riskiness
Note.— The table summarizes the testable implications of two theories of warrant inclusion in IPOs (initial public offerings). PIPO = package initial public offerings; SIPO = shares‐only initial public offerings.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: Our sample comprises 396 unseasoned issues of equity made between July 1, 1979, and December 31, 1990. We include in the sample only those IPOs for which a copy of the prospectus is available. From the prospectuses, we collect information on the firms’ offer price; the number of shares offered; the number of warrants offered (if any); the names of the underwriter(s) and accountant; the dates of incorporation, first operation, and prospectus registration; accounting information, such as total assets, total liabilities, and total tangible assets; and issuer share holdings. We obtain the aftermarket daily share and warrant prices from the Australian Stock Exchange’s (ASX) Statex database and theAustralian Financial Review.

Of the 396 IPOs in the sample, 134 (34%) are shares‐and‐warrants IPOs, and 262 are shares‐only IPOs. This proportion suggests that PIPOs are more common in Australia than in the United States. (About 21% of Schultz’s [1993b ] IPO sample are package IPOs.)Table 2, panel A, shows the distribution of the sample firms by the year of issue; panel B, the state of the market; panel C, the board of exchange; and panel D, the three broad industry classes of mining, high technology, and other industries. Note.— Distribution of 134 package initial public offerings (IPOs) and 262 shares‐only IPOs (SIPOs) by the year in which the IPO is made (panel A); the state of the market at the time the IPO is issued (panel B); the board of exchange, i.e., whether the IPO firm is from the Main Board or Second Board (panel C); and industry group (panel D). Package IPOs are initial public offerings of both common stock and warrants, and shares‐only IPOs are initial public offers of only common stock.
*
Mining firms have Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) codes 1–4: gold, other metals, solid fuels, and oil and gas.
†
High technology companies are listed under the ASX code 22.
‡
The “Other Industries” category includes all other firms, ASX codes 5–21.

We follow How, Izan, and Monroe (1995), identifying three states of the market—the pre‐1985 period (MV1), the boom period from 1985 to just before the October 1987 market crash (MV2), and the postcrash period (MV3).Table 2shows that the level of IPO activity correlates with market performance. For example, the number of IPOs is highest from 1985 until October 1987. The number of IPOs in our sample peaks in 1987 (180 offerings) and falls significantly in the later years. This pattern is similar to the “hot issue” IPO markets found in the United States (Ibbotson, Sindelar, and Ritter1988).

Prior to 1992, when the Second Board closed, companies in Australia were listed either on the Main Board or on the Second Board. The Second Board generally listed shares of newer firms, those not large enough to join the Main Board. Main Board listings required a minimum of A$300,000 in shareholders’ funds and a minimum of 300 shareholders. The requirements for Second Board listing were a minimum issued capital of A$100,000 and a minimum of 100 shareholders. In our sample, two‐thirds of the IPOs started trading on the Main Board.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Comparison of PIPO and SIPO Firms
sec.p:
Table 3provides descriptive statistics for characteristics of package IPO and shares‐only IPO firms. We adjust all (Australian) dollar‐denominated variables for inflation using the Consumer Price Index published inEconomic Indicatorby the Australian Bureau of Statistics. We use 1990 dollars. Table 3

Note.— Package IPOs are offers of both common stock and warrants, and shares‐only IPOs are initial public offers of only common stock. AGE is the number of calendar days from incorporation to listing; SIZE is the market capitalization of the firm, calculated as the post‐IPO market value of common stock and warrants (if any); TASSET is the pro forma value of total assets; SIGMA is the standard deviation of daily returns for the first 20‐day period, excluding the initial return; ALPHA is the percentage of shares held by issuers subsequent to the IPO; UWRITER denotes the reputation of the underwriter; ISSUE is the size of the offer; DEBT is the firm’s leverage, measured by the ratio of that debt to total tangible assets; DELAY is the number of calendar days from prospectus registration to listing. All dollar values are given in the Australian denomination restated in 1990 dollars. For tests of differences in means, we use the natural logarithm of AGE, SIZE, TASSET, ISSUE, and DELAY.
*
Significant at the 5% level (one‐tailed test).
**
Significant at the 1% level (one‐tailed test).

To assess the significance of the differences between our two samples, we reportt‐values from a parametric difference‐in‐means test andz‐scores from the Mann‐Whitney U‐test. We use the data in the table to examine both the first two implications of the agency‐cost hypothesis and the first implication of the signaling hypothesis.

The agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that package IPO firms will be younger than shares‐only IPO firms. PIPO firms are significantly younger, as measured by AGE, the number of calendar days from incorporation to listing.1The average (median) age is 618 (302) days for PIPO firms and 1,244 (376) days for shares‐only IPO firms. PIPO firms are also smaller than SIPO firms, regardless of whether size is measured by market capitalization (SIZE) or by the pro forma value of total assets (TASSET).

We follow Beatty (1989), measuring ex ante uncertainty (SIGMA) by the standard deviation of the first 20 days’ returns, excluding the initial daily return. Consistent with the prediction of both models, PIPO firms have significantly higher return volatility (SIGMA) than do SIPO firms. That is, PIPO firms are riskier than SIPO firms.

The second implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis focuses on the degree of managerial ownership in PIPO and SIPO firms. We do not have complete data on the share holdings of managers, but we are able to compute the percentage retained by issuers (ALPHA).
For those companies for which managerial ownership data are available, the measure is highly correlated with ALPHA; the correlation coefficient is 0.77, significant at the 1% level.

Table 3shows that the average percentage of ownership retained by issuers is about 13.5 percentage points higher for shares‐only IPOs than for PIPOs. The difference in medians is 15.6 percentage points. With lower levels of insider ownership, firms are likely to have greater agency costs and therefore are more likely to choose package IPOs. The data intable 3support this prediction of the agency‐cost hypothesis.

The second implication of the signaling hypothesis also deals with insider ownership: for PIPO firms, after controlling for the fraction of equity retained by insiders, the proportion of the firm sold as warrants increases with firm riskiness. We test this implication with the following regression (t‐statistics in parentheses), using the PIPO sample:
where we define XP.POST as the proceeds derived from the exercise of the warrants divided by the sum of the proceeds from the IPO plus the proceeds from the exercise of the warrants. The higher this number, the greater the percentage of the firm sold via the subsequent exercise of the warrants. The number represents the “number of warrants issued” variable in the Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) model. The signaling hypothesis predicts a positive coefficient on SIGMA. The evidence is consistent with this prediction.

Table 3shows a significant difference between PIPO and SIPO firms that is not predicted by either hypothesis. Package IPO firms have lower leverage than shares‐only IPO firms, as indicated by both the mean and median of DEBT, the pro forma ratio of total debt to total tangible assets. An alternative measure of leverage, total debt as a percent of market value of equity, supports this conclusion. This leverage measure (not reported in the table) has a mean of 5.76% for PIPO firms and 11.42% for SIPO firms. The medians are zero (PIPOs) and 1.24% (SIPOs). The PIPO firms’ lower level of debt might reflect an inability to tap the debt market to finance their (risky) projects.2The lower indebtedness of companies that choose package IPOs suggests that these firms are subject to less monitoring by banks and other creditors, which could make them more vulnerable to agency conflict.

Given the nature of Australian data, we cannot generate a measure of underwriter reputation directly comparable to that used in studies of U.S. initial public offerings. Instead, we calculate each underwriter’s underwriting frequency as a reputation measure, which we define as the number of times an underwriter was chosen to underwrite the sample firms. In some cases, there is a joint underwriting contract. We weight the underwriting frequency by the proportion of shares underwritten. That is, if underwriters A and B are responsible for 80% and 20%, respectively, of the shares in a given IPO, then we assign 0.80 to underwriter A and 0.20 to underwriter B. Typically, the proportion is equal across joint underwriters.3

The mean and median underwriter‐reputation metrics (UWRITER) are actually higher for package IPOs than for shares‐only IPOs. The difference is significant at the 5% level using thet‐test but insignificant at that level when we use the Mann‐Whitney U‐test. Thus, PIPO underwriters enjoy reputations at least as good as those of SIPO underwriters. Although our measure of underwriter reputation is different from those used in studies of U.S. IPOs, our finding is contrary to the U.S. experience, where very few package offerings are underwritten by prestigious underwriters.

Intable 3, offer size (ISSUE), which includes the proceeds from warrant subscriptions at the IPO for PIPO firms, is not significantly different across the two samples. We calculate DELAY, which we use as a proxy for Rock’s (1986) level of informed demand, as the number of calendar days between the registration of the prospectus and listing. Issues that sell more quickly have a higher level of informed demand. Later, we use DELAY as a control variable in the analysis of underpricing. Its mean is significantly higher for package IPOs, but its median is not.

To test whether the probability that a firm will choose a PIPO is related to the firm‐specific characteristics predicted by the agency‐cost and signaling hypotheses, we estimate the following logit model:
where PIPO i is the probability that theith firm will offer a package IPO andx
i is the column vector of independent variables. The logistic regression is
PIPO takes on a value of one for package IPOs and zero for shares‐only IPOs.

The agency‐cost hypothesis predicts negative coefficients on firm size (SIZE), firm age (AGE), and the proportion of shares held by issuers (ALPHA), and a positive coefficient on return volatility (SIGMA). The signaling hypothesis predicts a positive coefficient on SIGMA. The remaining right‐hand‐side variables are control variables, which we define as follows:
AUDITOR = one for Big Eight (Big Six) accountants, zero otherwise,
UWRITER = the reputation of the underwriter,
MINING = one for mining IPOs, zero otherwise,
MV1 = one for the pre‐1985 period, zero otherwise,
MV2 = one for the 1985–October 1987 period, zero otherwise.

Table 4shows the results from the logistic regression. The results indicate that SIZE is significantly, negatively related to the choice of a package offering. AGE is also significantly, negatively related to the IPO choice and shows that younger firms are more likely to choose a package IPO than are older firms. These findings are consistent with the first implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis. Table 4

Note.— The dependent variable is PIPO (package IPOs), which takes a value of one if package IPOs are issued and zero if shares‐only IPOs are issued. The independent variables tested are SIZE, the market capitalization of the firm, calculated as the post‐IPO market value of common stock and warrants (if any); AGE, the number of calendar days from incorporation to listing; ALPHA, the percentage of shares held by issuers subsequent to the IPO; SIGMA, the standard deviation of daily returns for the first 20‐day period, excluding the initial return. AUDITOR and UWRITER denote the reputation of the investigating accountant and the underwriter, respectively. MINING takes a value of one for mining IPOs and zero otherwise. MV1 and MV2 are time‐period‐indicator variables representing the periods pre‐1985 and 1985–October 1987, respectively. Tobin’sqis calculated as in Chung and Pruitt (1994). Standard errors are in parentheses.
*
Significant at the 5% level (one‐tailed test).
**
Significant at the 1% level (one‐tailed test).

The coefficient on post‐IPO return volatility is significantly positive, as predicted by both the agency‐cost hypothesis and signaling hypotheses. Further, package IPOs are more likely to be chosen by firms in which the issuers retain a smaller percentage of the shares (ALPHA). This finding is consistent with the second implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis.

The significant positive coefficient on the mining industry variable shows that mining firms are more likely to issue a package IPO.4The remaining variables are not significant at conventional levels. Hence, PIPOs are not more likely to be associated with a prestigious underwriter, auditor reputation has no significant association with the type of IPO chosen, and the decision to choose a package IPO does not depend on the time period.5

In the logistic analysis, we also include Tobin’sq,calculated as in Chung and Pruitt (1994). If the decision to choose a package IPO depends on the firm’s investment opportunity set, there should be a significant relation between Tobin’sqand the PIPO indicator variable. As the last column intable 4shows, there is no significant association.

fn.p: We also measure age by the number of calendar days from first operation to listing and the number of years of financial statements provided in the prospectus and use them in our tests. These measures yield results similar to those reported intable 3.

With a high percentage of firm value deriving from growth options, there is greater potential for conflicts between shareholders and bondholders (Smith and Watts1992), hence the low leverage of PIPO firms.

An alternative measure of underwriter reputation is the underwriter’s market share, calculated as the dollar value of all shares underwritten by the underwriter divided by the dollar value of all IPOs in the sample. Our conclusions are not sensitive to the choice of underwriter reputation measure.
However, we note that a substantial proportion of the mining firms in the sample (60 of 130) chose shares‐only IPOs.

We also use a Tobit regression, with the same right‐hand‐side variables, to explain the ratio of the proceeds from the exercise of the warrants to the IPO proceeds. The results are consistent with the logistic regressions reported intable 4.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Direct Tests
sec.p: The most straightforward test of the agency‐cost hypothesis examines whether PIPO firms have a greater level of agency costs than do SIPO firms. Perhaps the most straightforward test of the signaling hypothesis is that PIPO firms have higher levels of information asymmetry (and hence greater incentive to signal) than SIPO firms.

Following Ang et al. (2000), we use efficiency ratios as measures of agency costs. From data in the prospectuses, we calculate the following ratios, using data from the year before the IPO: operating revenue divided by total assets, earnings before interest and taxes divided by total assets, and operating profit after tax divided by total assets. We compute the mean and median of these measures for the SIPO and PIPO firms and assess the differences using both parametric and nonparametric tests.

Panel A oftable 5shows that in no case is there a significant difference in efficiency ratios between SIPO and PIPO firms. The first ratio in panel A, operating revenue standardized by total assets, gives a mean for PIPO firms that is higher than the mean for SIPO firms. (Recall that the agency‐cost hypothesis predicts the opposite, a higher mean for SIPO firms.) The median of this ratio is also higher for PIPO firms. The second ratio, EBIT as a percent of total assets, has a mean that is higher for SIPO firms, but it is not significantly higher. The medians of this ratio for SIPO and PIPO firms are both zero. The third ratio, operating profit after tax divided by total assets, is not significantly different across the two subsamples. Thus, the evidence on efficiency ratios provides no support for the agency‐cost hypothesis. The relatively small sample sizes prevent us from looking for industry or time‐period differences. Table 5
Direct Tests of the Agency‐Cost and Signaling Hypotheses

Note.— SIPO firms are those firms with shares‐only IPOs, and PIPO firms are those firms with package IPOs. Sample sizes are in brackets. Panel A: the table reports the means and medians (in parentheses) of three efficiency ratios, using data taken from the prospectuses for the year before the IPO. The table also reports thep‐values for parametric and nonparametric tests of differences. EBIT refers to earnings before interest and taxes. Panel B: the table reports the means and medians (in parentheses) of the residual standard deviations of the sample firms, estimated using daily data from the first year of trading, excluding the initial return. The table also reports thep‐values for parametric and nonparametric tests of differences. Mining, high tech, and “other” are the three industry categories. MV1 represents the period prior to 1985, MV2 represents the period from 1985 to October 1987, and MV3 represents the post–October 1987 period.

Following Krishnaswami et al. (1999) and Krishnaswami and Subramaniam (1999), we measure information asymmetry as the residual standard deviation from a market model regression. We use daily data for 1 year following the IPO, excluding the initial return. Panel B oftable 5shows our results. The mean (median) for the complete PIPO sample is 4.75% (5.84), and the mean (median) for the complete SIPO sample is 4.27% (3.90). Using both parametric and nonparametric tests, the differences are significant at the 5% level. Thus, PIPO firms exhibit more information asymmetry, as predicted by the signaling hypothesis.

The sample sizes for this metric are large enough for us to evaluate both industry and time‐period differences. Panel B oftable 5presents our findings. There is evidence of an industry effect: the residual standard deviation is higher for PIPO firms relative to SIPO firms for the “other industry” category. There is also some evidence of a time‐period effect: the earliest time period, 1979–84, is not characterized by differences in residual standard deviation between SIPO and PIPO firms. However, in the later periods, PIPO firms do have significantly higher levels of residual standard deviation than SIPO firms, as predicted by the signaling hypothesis.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Choice of Exercise Price
sec.p:
Table 6describes the warrants in the sample of package IPOs. Column 1 shows that the median number of shares per warrant is one (i.e., a package typically consists of one share and one warrant). The median time to expiration for the warrants offered in package IPOs is 1,023 calendar days (2.80 years), substantially less than the 4.75‐year median warrant life reported by Schultz (1993b ). Table 6
Warrents in Sample PIPOs
Shares per Warrant (1) Days to Expiration (2) Exercise Price (A$) (3) Exercise Price Divided by Share Offer Price (4) Proceeds from Exercise of Warrants Divided by IPO Proceeds (5) Proceeds from Exercise of Warrants (A$) (6) Proceeds from Warrant Subscription (A$) (7) IPO Proceeds (A$) (8)
A. Full sample of package IPOs:
Minimum .500 121 .200 .667 .102 149,440 0 149,440
Maximum 10.000 1,832 2.000 2.500 1.606 49,813,200 996,264 93,393,524
Median 1.000 1,023 .250 1.000 .581 2,490,660 0 3,363,332
Mean 1.653 1,037 .403 1.081 .578 4,988,827 83,452 7,533,622
B. Package IPOs partitioned into quartiles by issue size:
Quartile 1 1.309 1,070 .290 1.008 .707 149,440 0 1,314,527
Quartile 2 1.667 956 .350 1.090 .614 2,490,660 0 2,504,493
Quartile 3 1.706 1,031 .385 1.056 .534 5,219,948 13,967 4,434,645
Quartile 4 1.939 1,090 .589 1.154 .476 13,696,684 314,111 18,886,182
Note.— Description of warrants in sample package IPOs, which are initial public offers of both common stock and warrants. Quartiles are by issue size. The warrants are issued in package IPOs over the period 1979–90. A total of 134 IPO firms in the sample have package IPOs.

The median exercise price (X) is A$0.25. Although not shown in the table, the median offering price (OP) per share is also A$0.25. In most PIPOs, the exercise price is set near or equal to the offer price of the shares: for 112 firms (83.65%), the ratio of the exercise price (X) to the offering price (OP) is equal to one. In six cases (4.45%), X/OP is less than one, and the remaining 16 have X/OP ratios greater than one. This observation is contrary to the prediction of the agency‐cost hypothesis and weakly supports the signaling hypothesis.6

Table 6, column 5 compares the proceeds from exercising the warrants with the IPO proceeds. For the median firm, if all warrants are exercised, the money received is equal to about 58% of the proceeds received from the IPO. The average firm raises 42% less money from warrant exercise than from the IPO.

In many firms’ prospectuses, the warrant is listed as “free of charge.” For these firms, the proceeds from warrant subscription (col. 7) are shown as zero. Warrants are listed as “free of charge” because of a feature of the Australian tax code. If the warrants are issued at a positive price but are not exercised, the proceeds from their sale are subject to the corporate capital gains tax at the time of expiry or cancellation. If they are issued “free” and are not exercised, then there are no corporate or personal tax implications.

It is not entirely clear why all warrants are not issued free of charge, but there is a trade‐off: for shareholders, free options have a zero cost basis for personal capital gains tax purposes. When warrants are not “free,” it is common to find them offered for A$0.01.

Only two sample firms’ warrants, when exercised, grant a second (B) warrant in addition to a share. In contrast, Schultz (1993b ) reports that nearly 25% of U.S. PIPOs contain embedded warrants, which suggests that U.S. firms need more stages of financing.

The second part oftable 6partitions the package IPOs into quartiles by issue size. Three empirical regularities are evident. First, as issue size increases, the number of shares per warrant increases (col. 1). Because in a majority of issues the X/OP ratio is equal to one, this pattern suggests that for a relatively large offering, proportionately less will be raised by the (prospective) exercise of warrants. The data in column 5 confirm that the ratio of proceeds from the exercise of the warrants to the proceeds from the IPO declines as issue size increases.

Second, as issue size increases, so does the average exercise price (col. 3), primarily because larger offerings are associated with higher per‐share offer prices. Column 4 shows that the largest offerings (quartile 4) have the highest X/OP ratios. That is, the largest offerings are associated with the issuance of out‐of‐the‐money warrants.

Third, larger issue sizes are associated with larger dollar amounts of proceeds from the potential exercise of warrants (col. 6). Thus, although the proportion of total financing attributable to warrant exercise falls as issue size rises, the absolute dollar value of the second stage financing increases.

fn.p: Because the IPOs are typically underpriced, the warrants are effectively in the money. Although this is not exactly predicted by the signaling hypothesis, it is clearly contrary to the agency‐cost hypothesis. Kang et al. (1995) report that Japanese offshore warrants are “almost” at the money, as predicted by the signaling hypothesis.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Australian Warrants
sec.p: Comparing our data with Schultz’s (1993b ) study of U.S. package offerings shows systematic differences between U.S. and Australian warrants:

list-item.p: Australian warrants are shorter lived than U.S. warrants;

United States warrants are typically issued well out of the money. Schultz reports that for warrants issued in U.S. packages, the exercise price is roughly 25% above the issue price. As noted above, Australian warrants are frequently issued with the subscription price equal to the offer price of the shares;
Australian warrants rarely include embedded (B) warrants;
Australian warrants are not callable; most U.S. warrants are;
capital raised from the exercise of warrants relative to the capital raised in the initial offering is lower in Australia (58%) than in the United States (75%).

sec.p: We cannot fully explain these differences but offer the following observations. First, many of the PIPO firms are mining firms. Typically, the mining firm owns a short‐lived “exploration lease,” and the proceeds from the offering are used for a detailed geological assessment of the field(s). This process is not time consuming. Therefore, if the field shows a sufficiently high concentration of minerals, the firm will need additional financing soon after the IPO. Given the relatively short life of the warrant, it must be issued near or in the money in order to have any noticeable value.

Second, the inclusion of an embedded warrant creates a three‐stage sequence of financing: the initial offering, the exercise of the A warrants, and the exercise of the B warrants. Firms in some industries can have three or more distinct, additional stages when financing is needed—for example, product development, test marketing, and full scale production. We suspect that the near absence of embedded warrants in Australia arises because of differences in the investment opportunity set faced by Australian firms compared to U.S. companies.

Third, until recently, callable bonds faced a significant tax disadvantage in Australia, since their interest payments were not tax deductible. Thus, very few callable bonds were issued, and as a result, Australian investors have had little experience with callable securities. Perhaps more important, the callability of U.S. warrants is often used to force conversion (see Schultz1993a ). Given the relatively short lives of Australian warrants, this feature would be of little value.

Fourth, IPO firms in Australia appear to be earlier in the product cycle than are U.S. IPO firms. The median firm age in our sample is less than 1 year, compared to 5 years in the United States (Schultz1993b ). This observation could explain why U.S. firms raise relatively more money from the subsequent exercise of warrants than do Australian firms: without established technologies, products, or markets, Australian firms have little need for sizable cash infusions.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Failure Rates and Subsequent Financing
sec.p:
The fifth implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis is that PIPO firms are more likely to fail than are firms that issue only shares. The signaling hypothesis makes no prediction about relative failure rates. Schultz (1993b ) reports that only 58.8% of U.S. PIPO firms survive a full 3 years after their IPOs, compared with 88.9% of SIPO firms. Following Schultz, we count as surviving all firms that are not delistednyears after their IPOs.Table 7displays the survival rates of Australian firms 1, 2, and 3 years after their IPOs. Table 7
Survival Rates of PIPO and SIPO Firms (%)
1 Year 2 Years 3 Years
PIPO firms 99.3 97.8 89.6
SIPO firms 99.6 95.6 85.5
Note.— The percentage of PIPO (package initial public offering) and SIPO (shares‐only initial public offering) firms that survive 1, 2, and 3 years after their IPOs. We count as surviving all firms that are not delisted at the end of thenth year.

In contrast with the U.S. experience, 3 years after their IPOs, more Australian PIPO firms survive than do SIPO firms, although the difference is not significant. This evidence does not support the agency‐cost hypothesis.

We conduct two other tests of the failure rates of PIPO and SIPO firms (not reported here). First, we run logistic regressions to estimate the probability of failure within 1, 2, and 3 years. The coefficient on the PIPO indicator variable is not significant in any of the regressions.

Second, we define “failure” in terms of two return cutoffs, −50% and −70%, and track the number of firms that experience cumulative returns less than these cutoffs in each of the 3 years following their IPOs. There was no significant difference in any year in the proportion of PIPO and SIPO firms that “exceeded” these cutoffs.

The sixth implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis is that PIPO firms delay equity financing until the profitability of their investment project(s) is verified. This reasoning implies that PIPO firms are more likely to receive additional equity financing following their IPOs. The signaling hypothesis has no comparable implication.

To test this prediction of the agency‐cost hypothesis, we consult the seasoned equity offerings (SEO) database at the Curtin Business School. These data end on June 30, 1992. Therefore, we exclude firms listed after June 30, 1989, so that we can track each firm for 3 years after its IPO. Also, the database does not include Second Board companies. Because of these limitations, we have data for 274 IPOs, of which 184 are shares‐only IPOs and 90 are package IPOs.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: Underpricing
sec.p: The last implication of the agency‐cost hypothesis is that PIPOs are more underpriced than are SIPOs. We examine this issue in two ways.

First,Table 8reports the average underpricing for the entire sample and separately for the SIPO and PIPO samples. We use four measures of underpricing. The discrete initial return, shown as RET1 in the table, is ( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $P_{1}-P_{0}$ \end{document} )/P 0, whereP 1is the closing price on the first day of trading, andP 0is the offer price. The continuously compounded initial return is ln( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $1+\mathrm{RET}\,1$ \end{document} ) and is reported as RET2 in the table. We define the discrete market‐adjusted return, RET3, as RET1 minus the market return over the same horizon. RET4 is the continuously compounded equivalent of RET3, equal to ln( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $1+\mathrm{RET}\,3$ \end{document} ). The table also reports median, minimum, and maximum underpricing measures. Table 8

Shares‐only IPOs ( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $N=262$ \end{document} ):

40.22 10.86 −70.76 250.04
C. Package IPOs ( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $N=134$ \end{document} ):
RET1 68.57 .161 217.27 15.19 −64.52 2,180.00
RET2 28.46 .272 57.14 14.14 −103.61 312.68
RET3 68.47 .159 217.17 14.24 −64.87 2,179.13
RET4 28.36 .262 57.10 13.22 −103.96 311.81
Note.— Thep‐value is for differences‐in‐means test, shares‐only IPOs vs. package IPOs. The RET1 is the discrete initial return, calculated from the offer price to the closing price on the first day of trading; RET2 is the continuously compounded initial return; RET3 is the discrete market‐adjusted initial return; and RET4 is RET3’s continuously compounded equivalent. Package IPOs are initial public offers of both common stock and warrants, and shares‐only IPOs are offers of only common stock.

Three other measures of underpricing reported intable 8lead to the same conclusion. Despite the appearance of differences in the degrees of underpricing between package and shares‐only IPOs, the differences are not statistically significant at conventional levels.

We also examine underpricing by industry classification and trading location (Main Board or Second Board). We do not report the results, but in no case are PIPOs significantly more underpriced than SIPOs.

Second, to analyze further the relation between the type of IPO and underpricing, we estimate a simultaneous system of equations that we believe reflects the spirit of the Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) model. In their model, underpricing (RET in the equations below), the fraction of equity to be retained (ALPHA), and the number of warrants to be issued are the three major variables. We use XP.POST as our proxy for the number of warrants issued. We define this number as the proceeds derived from the exercise of the warrants divided by the sum of the proceeds from the IPO plus the proceeds from the exercise of the warrants. (This is the same variable that appears ineq. [1]and is a measure of the proportion of firm value sold as warrants.) We estimate the following system using two‐stage least squares:7
We use the continuously compounded market‐adjusted initial return (RET3 intable 8) as the underpricing measure RET. Although not reported, use of other initial return measures yields results nearly identical to those reported in the article.

The independent variables in the underpricing equation reflect both the variables in the Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) signaling model and previous findings on the determinants of underpricing. We include issue size (ISSUE) because larger issues might require more underpricing. Alternatively, larger issues could be associated with less information asymmetry and perhaps less underpriced.

Beatty and Ritter (1986) find a significant positive relation between ex ante uncertainty and underpricing. Ritter (1984), Chalk and Peavy (1987), Wolfe and Cooperman (1990), and How et al. (1995) report that larger, older IPOs are generally less underpriced. The evidence in Beatty (1989), Carter and Manaster (1990), and Balvers, McDonald, and Miller (1988) shows that IPOs associated with high‐reputation accountants and underwriters are significantly less underpriced, presumably because of the certification function that they perform.

We use DELAY, measured as the time lag between the prospectus registration and listing dates, as a proxy for Rock’s (1986) level of informed demand for the IPO. Issues that sell more quickly have a higher level of informed demand. We can therefore expect them to be more underpriced. Issues that sell more slowly are likely to be less underpriced because of a lack of interest on the part of informed investors. Lee, Taylor, and Walter (1996) and How et al. (1995) find that DELAY is a significant explanatory variable for Australian IPO underpricing.

The evidence in Ritter (1984) suggests that underpricing is dependent on market conditions. How et al. (1995) observe similar behavior in Australia, where they find that underpricing is greater during “boom” than “bear” periods. Inequation (4), we use MV1 and MV2 as dummy variables to control for the state of the market at the time of the IPO. Here, MV3, which takes a value of one for IPOs occurring subsequent to the 1987 crash, is the base case.

MINING is an indicator variable that captures mining industry influences. It is set equal to one for mining IPOs, zero otherwise. To control for board‐specific effects, we use the dummy variable XBOARD, which takes a value of one for Main Board IPOs and zero for Second Board IPOs.

We include the variable XP.POST for two reasons: first, because it represents one of the variables (number of warrants) within the Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1997) model; second, because it serves as a quasi‐indicator variable, taking on the value of zero for all SIPOs and positive values for PIPOs. Finally, we include ALPHA, a measure of retained ownership, because it too is endogenous in the signaling model.

Table 9displays the results of the two‐stage least squares estimation. Equation (A) is the underpricing equation. The agency‐cost hypothesis predicts that the coefficient on XP.POST will be positive. The coefficient is positive, but it is not significant at conventional levels.8
Table 9

Note.— We estimate this system of equations using two‐stage least squares. The dependent variable RET in eq. (A) is the continuously compounded market‐adjusted initial return (the underpricing measure). The dependent variable in eq. (B) is XP.POST, the proceeds derived from the exercise of the warrants divided by the sum of the proceeds from the IPO plus the proceeds from the exercise of the warrants. The dependent variable in eq. (C) is ALPHA, the percentage of shares held by issuers subsequent to the IPO. The other variables are ISSUE, the offer size, restated in 1990 dollars; SIGMA, the standard deviation of daily returns for the first 20‐day period, excluding the initial return; AGE, the number of calendar days from incorporation to listing; DEBT, total debt divided by total tangible assets. AUDITOR and UWRITER denote the reputation of the investigating accountant and the underwriter, respectively. DELAY is the number of calendar days from prospectus registration to listing. MV1 and MV2 control for the state of the market at the time of the IPO. MINING takes a value of one for mining IPOs and zero otherwise. XBOARD takes a value of one for Main Board IPOs and zero otherwise.
*
Significant at the 5% level.
**
Significant at the 1% level.

The signaling hypothesis predicts a positive coefficient on SIGMA, a prediction that underpricing will increase with riskiness. In contrast to Beatty and Ritter (1986), the positive relation between our proxy for ex ante uncertainty (SIGMA) and underpricing is not significant. However, this finding is consistent with earlier findings on Australian IPOs (Finn and Higham1988).

Equation (A) also confirms previous findings on the determinants of underpricing: the longer the time from prospectus registration to listing, the less the underpricing, as indicated by the significantly negative coefficient of DELAY; the degree of underpricing depends on the state of the market at the time the IPO is issued, as shown by the coefficients of MV1 and MV2; and industry factors significantly influence the degree to which IPOs are underpriced. Mining companies are more underpriced than other industries, all else equal.

In our sample, the size of the issue, firm age, the reputation effects of the accountant and the underwriter, and trading location are not significant explanatory variables for IPO underpricing. Overall, equation (A) provides no support for either the agency‐cost hypothesis or the signaling hypothesis.

fn.p: We also estimate the system using the Seemingly Unrelated Regression (SUR) approach, with similar results.
When we use a [0,1] indicator variable in place of XP.POST, the coefficient remains insignificant.

sec.label: G.
sec.title: Insider Ownership and Warrants—the Signaling Hypothesis
sec.p: The last implication of the signaling hypothesis is that after controlling for the fraction of equity retained by insiders (ALPHA), the proportion of firm value sold as warrants increases with firm riskiness. This implication is tested in equation (B) intable 9. The left‐hand‐side variable is XP.POST, the proceeds derived from the exercise of the warrants divided by the sum of the proceeds from the IPO plus the proceeds from the exercise of the warrants. In addition to ALPHA and RET, the right‐hand‐side variables include the offering size, the riskiness of the firm, firm age, auditor and underwriter reputation measures, time period indicator variables, and a mining dummy variable.

The signaling hypothesis predicts a positive coefficient on SIGMA, the riskiness of the firm. The coefficient is positive and is significant at the 1% level. Thus, the sixth prediction of the signaling hypothesis receives strong support in equation (B).

Using the simultaneous equation system reported intable 9, we can revisit the second prediction of the signaling hypothesis, originally tested in a single equation framework. The signaling model predicts a negative coefficient on SIGMA in equation (C). That coefficient is significantly negative at the 5% level, confirming the earlier single‐equation findings.9

fn.p: Actually, the signaling hypothesis predicts this relation only for PIPO firms, and eq. (C) is run with both SIPO and PIPO firms. However, the equation includes XP.POST, which, as argued earlier, acts as a quasi‐indicator variable for SIPO firms.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Summary and Conclusions
sec.p: Why does a firm include warrants in its initial public offering? The literature contains two explanations. The agency‐cost hypothesis emphasizes the need for sequential financing for relatively young firms, because sequential financing reduces the opportunities for managers to squander money on unprofitable projects. The signaling hypothesis focuses on the choice of securities as a signaling mechanism in a market characterized by information asymmetry.

The two theories make similar predictions about the riskiness, age, size, and insider ownership of firms that include warrants in their initial public offerings, and the data support these predictions. However, the theories have several distinctive implications and are thus empirically distinguishable. The unique implications of the agency‐cost hypothesis are generally not supported by our data, but the data are largely consistent with the implications of the signaling hypothesis.

These findings are important, because the finance profession has developed an increased interest in the types and characteristics of securities issued by firms. The research presented here contributes to our understanding of these issues. We provide evidence that supports the signaling hypothesis explanation for the inclusion of warrants in IPOs, and we explain some of the characteristics of Australian warrants in the context of the institutional setting there.

ref.mixed-citation: Ang, J. S.; Cole, R. A.; and Lin, J. W. 2000. Agency costs and ownership structure.Journal of Finance55:81–106.
